concept.title: Lubrication Guidelines for Typewriters
concept.shortdesc: Proper lubrication is essential for maintaining the smooth operation and longevity of typewriter components.

conbody.p: Portable typewriters do not need regular lubrication. However, metal-on-metal components can develop friction, requiring occasional lubrication.
Only use light weight oils. Acceptable oils include sewing machine oils, gun oils, and specialized typewriter lubricants.
conbody.note: Never use heavy oils, like motor oils and other household lubricants. Heavy oils will cause gears and links to gum up over time.
Never lubricate rubber components, such as the platen, feeder, or paper bail rollers. Oil will degrade rubber, and transfer oil onto the ink ribbon and typing paper.
Avoid lubricating the segment, vibrator mechanics, and line spacing mechanics. These components are susceptible to attracting dust and debris.
conbody.p: Identify metal-on-metal connections, gears, and pivot points that are hesitant in movement or completely stiff. Common areas that require lubrication include the carriage rails and internal pivot points, levers, and gears.
conbody.note: It is important to not excessively lubricate a typewriter. Even light weight lubricants will attract debris over time, causing damage. Use minimal oil, and wipe away excess as you go.
